paragraphs.text: %md ## Streaming Data MapR Event Store is a distributed publish-subscribe event streaming system that enables producers and consumers to exchange events in real time in a parallel and fault-tolerant manner via the Apache Kafka API. A stream represents a continuous sequence of events that goes from producers to consumers, where an event is defined as a key-value pair. The Streaming event values have the following format: {"id":"ATL_BOS_2018-01-01_DL_104","fldate":"2018-01-01","month":1,"dofW":1, "carrier":"DL","src":"ATL","dst":"BOS","crsdephour":9,"crsdeptime":850,"depdelay":0.0, "crsarrtime":1116,"arrdelay":0.0,"crselapsedtime":146.0,"dist":946.0} We will use the machine learning model to enrich the events with the flight delay label and predictions and we will store the results in MapR Database.

msg.data:
Streaming Data

MapR Event Store is a distributed publish-subscribe event streaming system that enables producers and consumers to exchange events in real time in a parallel and fault-tolerant manner via the Apache Kafka API.
A stream represents a continuous sequence of events that goes from producers to consumers, where an event is defined as a key-value pair.

The Streaming event values have the following format:

{“id”:“ATL_BOS_2018-01-01_DL_104”,“fldate”:“2018-01-01”,“month”:1,“dofW”:1,
“carrier”:“DL”,“src”:“ATL”,“dst”:“BOS”,“crsdephour”:9,“crsdeptime”:850,“depdelay”:0.0,
“crsarrtime”:1116,“arrdelay”:0.0,“crselapsedtime”:146.0,“dist”:946.0}

We will use the machine learning model to enrich the events with the flight delay label and predictions and we will store the results in MapR Database.

paragraphs.text: %md ## Spark Structured Streaming Structured Streaming is a scalable and fault-tolerant stream processing engine built on the Spark SQL engine. Structured Streaming enables you to view data published to Kafka as an unbounded DataFrame and process this data with the same DataFrame, Dataset, and SQL APIs used for batch processing.

msg.data:
Spark Structured Streaming

Structured Streaming is a scalable and fault-tolerant stream processing engine built on the Spark SQL engine. Structured Streaming enables you to view data published to Kafka as an unbounded DataFrame and process this data with the same DataFrame, Dataset, and SQL APIs used for batch processing.

paragraphs.title: Import needed packages
paragraphs.text:
%spark
import org.apache.spark.sql.SparkSession
import org.apache.spark.sql.types._
import org.apache.spark.sql.functions._
import org.apache.spark.sql._
import org.apache.spark.streaming._

import org.apache.spark.ml._
import org.apache.spark.ml.feature._
import org.apache.spark.ml.classification._
import org.apache.spark.ml.evaluation._
import org.apache.spark.ml.tuning._

paragraphs.text:
%spark
case class Flight(id: String, fldate: String, month: Integer, dofW: Integer, carrier: String,src: String, dst: String, crsdephour: Integer, crsdeptime: Integer,depdelay: Double, crsarrtime: Integer, arrdelay: Double, crselapsedtime:Double, dist: Double, orig_dest: String, label: Double, prediction: Double)

msg.data: defined class Flight

paragraphs.title: Define Schema for JSON streaming data
paragraphs.text:
import org.apache.spark.sql.types._

// {“id”:“ATL_BOS_2018-01-01_DL_104”,“fldate”:“2018-01-01”,“month”:1,“dofW”:1,
//“carrier”:“DL”,“src”:“ATL”,“dst”:“BOS”,“crsdephour”:9,“crsdeptime”:850,“depdelay”:0.0,
//“crsarrtime”:1116,“arrdelay”:0.0,“crselapsedtime”:146.0,“dist”:946.0}

  val schema = StructType(Array(
    StructField("id", StringType, true),
    StructField("fldate", StringType, true),
    StructField("month", IntegerType, true),
    StructField("dofW", IntegerType, true),
    StructField("carrier", StringType, true),
    StructField("src", StringType, true),
    StructField("dst", StringType, true),
    StructField("crsdephour", IntegerType, true),
    StructField("crsdeptime", IntegerType, true),
    StructField("depdelay", DoubleType, true),
    StructField("crsarrtime", IntegerType, true),
    StructField("arrdelay", DoubleType, true),
    StructField("crselapsedtime", DoubleType, true),
    StructField("dist", DoubleType, true)
  ))

val model = org.apache.spark.ml.PipelineModel.load(modeldirectory)

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Reading Data from Kafka Topics
In order to read from Kafka, we must first specify the stream format, topic, and offset options.For more information on the configuration parameters

msg.data:
Reading Data from Kafka Topics

In order to read from Kafka, we must first specify the stream format, topic, and offset options.For more information on the configuration parameters

paragraphs.title: Read Stream from Kafka topic
paragraphs.text: val df1 = spark.readStream.format("kafka").option("kafka.bootstrap.servers", "maprdemo:9092").option("subscribe", topic).option("group.id", "testgroup").option("startingOffsets", "earliest").option("failOnDataLoss", false).option("maxOffsetsPerTrigger", 1000).load()

msg.data: df1: org.apache.spark.sql.DataFrame = [key: binary, value: binary ... 5 more fields]

paragraphs.title: Print DataFrame Schema
paragraphs.text:
// readStream.format "kafka" returns a DataFrame with the following schema:
df1.printSchema

msg.data:
root
 |-- key: binary (nullable = true)
 |-- value: binary (nullable = true)
 |-- topic: string (nullable = true)
 |-- partition: integer (nullable = true)
 |-- offset: long (nullable = true)
 |-- timestamp: timestamp (nullable = true)
 |-- timestampType: integer (nullable = true)

paragraphs.text:
%md
The next step is to parse and transform the binary values column into a Dataset of Flight schema.
In the code below: 
* first we use a select expression with a String Cast of the df1 column value to convert the value from binary to string
* then we use the from_json Spark SQL function in a select expression to retrieve the JSON string as the specified schema StructTyp

msg.data:
The next step is to parse and transform the binary values column into a Dataset of Flight schema.
In the code below:
* first we use a select expression with a String Cast of the df1 column value to convert the value from binary to string
* then we use the from_json Spark SQL function in a select expression to retrieve the JSON string as the specified schema StructTyp

paragraphs.title: Parse the Message Values into a Dataframe of Flight Schema

msg.data: df2: org.apache.spark.sql.DataFrame = [id: string, fldate: string ... 12 more fields]

paragraphs.text:
// add column orig_dest, needed feature for ML model
 val df3 = df2.withColumn("orig_dest", concat($"src", lit("_"), $"dst"))

msg.data: df3: org.apache.spark.sql.DataFrame = [id: string, fldate: string ... 13 more fields]

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Enriching the flight Dataframe with label and predictions
We transform the DataFrame with the model pipeline, which will tranform the features according to the pipeline, estimate and then return the predictions in a column of a new DateFrame.

msg.data:
Enriching the flight Dataframe with label and predictions

We transform the DataFrame with the model pipeline, which will tranform the features according to the pipeline, estimate and then return the predictions in a column of a new DateFrame.
predictions: org.apache.spark.sql.DataFrame = [id: string, fldate: string ... 23 more fields]

paragraphs.text:
// select the columns that we want to store
val lp = predictions.select($"id",$"fldate", $"month", $"dofW", $"carrier", $"src", $"dst", $"crsdephour", $"crsdeptime", $"depdelay", $"crsarrtime",$"arrdelay", $"crselapsedtime",$"dist", $"orig_dest", $"label", $"prediction").as[Flight]

paragraphs.text:
import com.mapr.db.spark.impl._
import com.mapr.db.spark.streaming._
import com.mapr.db.spark.sql._
import com.mapr.db.spark.streaming.MapRDBSourceConfig
val writedb = lp.writeStream.format(MapRDBSourceConfig.Format).option(MapRDBSourceConfig.TablePathOption, tableName).option(MapRDBSourceConfig.IdFieldPathOption, "id").option(MapRDBSourceConfig.CreateTableOption, false).option("checkpointLocation", "/tmp/flight").option(MapRDBSourceConfig.BulkModeOption, true).option(MapRDBSourceConfig.SampleSizeOption, 1000).start()

from flights

paragraphs.title: Calculate some more metrics
paragraphs.text:
val lp = df.select( "label", "prediction")
val counttotal = lp.count().toDouble
val correct = lp.filter($"label" === $"prediction").count().toDouble
val wrong = lp.filter(not($"label" === $"prediction")).count().toDouble
val truep =( lp.filter($"label" === 1.0).filter($"label" === $"prediction").count()) /counttotal
val truen = (lp.filter($"label" === 0.0).filter($"label" === $"prediction").count())/counttotal
val falsep = (lp.filter($"label" === 1.0).filter(not($"label" === $"prediction")).count())/counttotal
val falsen = (lp.filter($"label" === 0.0).filter(not($"label" === $"prediction")).count())/counttotal
val ratioWrong=wrong/counttotal
val ratioCorrect=correct/counttotal
val precision = truep / (truep + falsep)
